question: How long does it take VA to make a decision?
ground_truths: [' 103.3 days, the average number of days to complete disability-related claims in September 2023']
answer: The time it takes for the VA to make a decision on a claim depends on several factors including the type of claim filed, the number and complexity of injuries or disabilities claimed, and how long it takes to collect the necessary evidence to decide the claim. As of September 2023, the average number of days to complete disability-related claims was 103.3 days.

question: what are the factors for determing the time it will take my claim?
ground_truths: ['The type of claim you filed.\nHow many injuries or disabilities you claimed and how complex they are.\nHow long it takes us to collect the evidence we need to decide your claim.']
answer:
The time it takes to review your claim depends on these factors:

1. The type of claim you filed
2. How many injuries or disabilities you claimed and how complex they are
3. How long it takes to collect the evidence needed to decide your claim

question: What should I do if I disagree with my VA disability claim decision?
ground_truths: ['If you disagree with a claim decision that you received on or after February 19, 2019, you can ask us to review the decision. You have 3 decision review options to choose from.']
answer: If you disagree with a VA disability claim decision that you received on or after February 19, 2019, you can ask the Veterans Affairs to review the decision. You have three decision review options to choose from.

Learn what the PACT Act means for your VA benefits ', metadata={'source': '/Users/yinchangli/guardian/guardian/data/The VA Claim Process After You File Your Claim _ Veterans Affairs.pdf', 'page': 2}), Document(page_content='11/19/23, 9:18 AM How To File A VA Disability Claim | Veterans Affairs
https://www.va.gov/disability/how-to-ﬁle-claim/ 2/5What evidence do I need to support
my claim?
You can support your VA disability claim by providing these documents:
VA medical records and hospital records. These could\xa0relate to your
claimed illnesses or injuries or they could\xa0show that your rated disability has
gotten worse.
Private medical records and hospital reports. These could\xa0relate to your
claimed illnesses or injuries or they could\xa0show that your disability has
gotten worse.
Supporting statements. These could be from family members, friends,
clergy members, law enforcement personnel, or people\xa0you served with.
These statements\xa0could\xa0tell us more about your claimed condition and how
and when it happened or how it got worse.
Depending on the type of claim you file, you may gather supporting documents
yourself, or you can ask for our help to gather evidence.
Learn more about the evidence we’ll need for your claim
(https://www.va.gov/disability/how-to-file-claim/evidence-needed)
We’ll also review your discharge papers (DD214 or other separation documents)
and service treatment records.
Do I have to submit evidence with
my claim?
No. You don’t have to submit any evidence to support your claim. But we may
need to schedule a claim exam so we can learn more about your condition.
You should also know that you have up to a year from the date we receive your
claim to turn in any evidence. If you start your application and need time to
gather more supporting documents, you can save your application and come
back later to finish it. We’ll recognize the date you started your application as
your date of claim as long as you complete it within 365 days.
Learn what the PACT Act means for your VA benefits ', metadata={'source': '/Users/yinchangli/guardian/guardian/data/How To File A VA Disability Claim _ Veterans Affairs.pdf', 'page': 1}), Document(page_content='11/19/23, 9:18 AM How To File A VA Disability Claim | Veterans Affairs

claimed illnesses or injuries or they could\xa0show that your rated disability has
gotten worse.
Private medical records and hospital reports. These could\xa0relate to your
claimed illnesses or injuries or they could\xa0show that your disability has
gotten worse.
Supporting statements. These could be from family members, friends,
clergy members, law enforcement personnel, or people\xa0you served with.
These statements\xa0could\xa0tell us more about your claimed condition and how
and when it happened or how it got worse.
Depending on the type of claim you file, you may gather supporting documents
yourself, or you can ask for our help to gather evidence.
Learn more about the evidence we’ll need for your claim
(https://www.va.gov/disability/how-to-file-claim/evidence-needed)
We’ll also review your discharge papers (DD214 or other separation documents)
and service treatment records.
Do I have to submit evidence with
my claim?
No. You don’t have to submit any evidence to support your claim. But we may
need to schedule a claim exam so we can learn more about your condition.
You should also know that you have up to a year from the date we receive your
claim to turn in any evidence. If you start your application and need time to
gather more supporting documents, you can save your application and come
back later to finish it. We’ll recognize the date you started your application as
your date of claim as long as you complete it within 365 days.
Learn what the PACT Act means for your VA benefits ', metadata={'source': '/Users/yinchangli/guardian/guardian/data/How To File A VA Disability Claim _ Veterans Affairs.pdf', 'page': 1})]

question: How can I change my VA direct deposit information online?
ground_truths: ['If you receive disability compensation, pension, or education benefits from VA, you can update your direct deposit information in your VA.gov profile. You’ll need your bank’s routing number and account number to make the updates.']
answer: To change your VA direct deposit information online, you need to sign in to your VA.gov profile. If you receive disability compensation, pension, or education benefits from VA, you can update your direct deposit information there. You will need your bank's routing number and account number to make the updates. If you haven't already, you'll need to verify your identity and set up 2-factor authentication. You can sign in with your existing Login.gov or ID.me account, or create one of these accounts. Note that if you sign in with a DS Logon or My HealtheVet account, you won't be able to change your direct deposit information.

question: What if I don’t have a bank account, but I want to use direct deposit?
ground_truths: ['The Veterans Benefits Banking Program (VBBP) provides a list of Veteran-friendly banks and credit unions that will work with you to set up an account, or help you qualify for an account, so you can use direct deposit.\nTo get started, call one of the participating banks or credit unions listed on the VBBP website. Be sure to mention the Veterans Benefits Banking Program.']
answer: If you don't have a bank account but want to use direct deposit, you can take advantage of the Veterans Benefits Banking Program (VBBP). This program provides a list of Veteran-friendly banks and credit unions that will work with you to set up an account, or help you qualify for an account, so you can use direct deposit. To get started, you can call one of the participating banks or credit unions listed on the VBBP website and mention the Veterans Benefits Banking Program.

sf-1199a)

account , but I want  to use di rect
de posit?
The\xa0Veterans Benefits Banking Program\xa0(VBBP) provides a list of Veteran-friendly
banks and credit unions that will work with you to\xa0set up an account, or help you
qualify for an account,\xa0so you can use direct deposit.\xa0
To get started, call one of the participating banks or credit unions listed on the
VBBP website. Be sure to mention the Veterans Benefits Banking Program.
Go to the VBBP website for more information
(https://veteransbenefitsbanking.org/)
More inform ation

question: What evidence does VA need to support my disability claim?
ground_truths: ['We need evidence that shows that both of these descriptions are true: You have a current physical or mental disability (damage to your body or mind that makes you less able—or totally unable—to do everyday tasks, including meaningful work), and An event, injury, or illness happened while you were serving in the military to cause this disability']
answer:
The VA needs evidence that shows both of the following descriptions are true: 

1. You have a current physical or mental disability (damage to your body or mind that makes you less able—or totally unable—to do everyday tasks, including meaningful work), and 
2. An event, injury, or illness happened while you were serving in the military to cause this disability.

The documents you'll need to support your claim include your DD214 or other separation documents, your service treatment records, and any medical evidence related to your illness or injury (like doctor’s reports, X-rays, and medical test results). You can also provide VA medical records and hospital records, private medical records and hospital reports, and supporting statements from family members, friends, clergy members, law enforcement personnel, or people you served with.

https://www.va.gov/disability/how-to-ﬁle-claim/ 2/5What evidence do I need to support
my claim?
You can support your VA disability claim by providing these documents:
VA medical records and hospital records. These could\xa0relate to your
claimed illnesses or injuries or they could\xa0show that your rated disability has
gotten worse.
Private medical records and hospital reports. These could\xa0relate to your
claimed illnesses or injuries or they could\xa0show that your disability has
gotten worse.
Supporting statements. These could be from family members, friends,
clergy members, law enforcement personnel, or people\xa0you served with.
These statements\xa0could\xa0tell us more about your claimed condition and how
and when it happened or how it got worse.
Depending on the type of claim you file, you may gather supporting documents
yourself, or you can ask for our help to gather evidence.
Learn more about the evidence we’ll need for your claim
(https://www.va.gov/disability/how-to-file-claim/evidence-needed)
We’ll also review your discharge papers (DD214 or other separation documents)
and service treatment records.
Do I have to submit evidence with
my claim?
No. You don’t have to submit any evidence to support your claim. But we may
need to schedule a claim exam so we can learn more about your condition.
You should also know that you have up to a year from the date we receive your
claim to turn in any evidence. If you start your application and need time to
gather more supporting documents, you can save your application and come
back later to finish it. We’ll recognize the date you started your application as
your date of claim as long as you complete it within 365 days.
Learn what the PACT Act means for your VA benefits ', metadata={'source': '/Users/yinchangli/guardian/guardian/data/How To File A VA Disability Claim _ Veterans Affairs.pdf', 'page': 1}), Document(page_content='11/19/23, 9:18 AM How To File A VA Disability Claim | Veterans Affairs

Supporting statements. These could be from family members, friends,

These statements\xa0could\xa0tell us more about your claimed condition and how

Depending on the type of claim you file, you may gather supporting documents
yourself, or you can ask for our help to gather evidence.
Learn more about the evidence we’ll need for your claim
(https://www.va.gov/disability/how-to-file-claim/evidence-needed)

No. You don’t have to submit any evidence to support your claim. But we may

You should also know that you have up to a year from the date we receive your

back later to finish it. We’ll recognize the date you started your application as
your date of claim as long as you complete it within 365 days.

question: What happens after I file my VA disability claim?
ground_truths: ['You don’t need to do anything while you’re waiting unless we send you a letter asking for more information. If we schedule exams for you, be sure not to miss them.']
answer:
After you file your VA disability claim, the following steps occur:

1. Claim received: The VA will let you know when they receive your claim. If you file online, you'll get an on-screen message after you submit the form. If you mail your application, they'll send you a letter about 1 week, plus mailing time, after they receive your claim.

2. Initial review: The VA will review your claim. If they don't need any more evidence to support it, your claim will move to the next step.

3. Evidence gathering, review, and decision: During this step, the VA may ask for evidence from you, health care providers, government agencies, or others. They will review the evidence and make a decision.

4. Preparation for notification: The VA will prepare your claim decision packet to mail.

5. Claim complete: The VA will send you a packet by U.S. mail that includes details of the decision on your claim. Please allow 7 to 10 business days for your packet to arrive before contacting a VA call center.

Remember, you don't need to do anything unless the VA sends you a letter asking for more information. If they schedule any exams for you, be sure not to miss them. You can check the status of your claim online. The timeline may vary based on how complex your claim is.

question: Can I submit a fully developed disability claim?
ground_truths: ['You can submit a fully developed disability claim if you’re applying for compensation for: An illness or injury (also called a condition) that was caused by—or got worse because of—your active-duty service, or A condition that was caused—or made worse—by a disability we’ve already determined is service-connected']
answer: Yes, you can submit a fully developed disability claim if you're applying for compensation for an illness or injury that was caused by—or got worse because of—your active-duty service, or a condition that was caused—or made worse—by a disability that's already been determined as service-connected.
contexts:
[Document(page_content='11/19/23, 9:17 AM VA Fully Developed Claims Program | Veterans Affairs
https://www.va.gov/disability/how-to-ﬁle-claim/evidence-needed/fully-developed-claims/ 1/5VA Fully Developed Claims
program
Find out  ho w you can us e the  Ful ly Developed Claim s
program  to get a faster decision on your  disability
benefits claim  by sub m itting evidence along with your
claim .
Can I submit a fully developed
disability claim?
You can submit a fully developed disability claim if you’re applying for
compensation for:
An illness or injury (also called a condition) that was caused by—or got
worse because of—your active-duty service, or
A condition that was caused—or made worse—by a disability we’ve
already determined is service-connected
What do I need to do to submit a
fully developed claim?
For us to consider your claim fully developed, you’ll need to:
Submit your completed Application for Disability Compensation and
Related Compensation Benefits (VA Form 21-526EZ), and
Submit all the evidence (supporting documents) you have—or can
easily get—along with your claim, and
Certify that there’s no more evidence we might need to decide your
claim, and
Go to any VA medical exams required for us to decide your claim. We’ll
let you know if you need any exams.In this section
Learn what the PACT Act means for your VA benefits  ', metadata={'source': '/Users/yinchangli/guardian/guardian/data/VA Fully Developed Claims Program _ Veterans Affairs.pdf', 'page': 0}), Document(page_content='11/19/23, 9:17 AM VA Fully Developed Claims Program | Veterans Affairs

Learn what the PACT Act means for your VA benefits  ', metadata={'source': '/Users/yinchangli/guardian/guardian/data/VA Fully Developed Claims Program _ Veterans Affairs.pdf', 'page': 0}), Document(page_content='11/19/23, 9:17 AM VA Fully Developed Claims Program | Veterans Affairs
https://www.va.gov/disability/how-to-ﬁle-claim/evidence-needed/fully-developed-claims/ 2/5What evidence will I need to
submit along with my disability
claim?
You’ll need to send us:
All private medical records related to the claimed condition, like reports from
your own doctor or X-rays or other test results from a non-VA hospital or
other treatment center, and
Any records of medical treatment you’ve received for the claimed condition
while serving in the military, and
Any military personnel records you have that relate to the claimed condition,
and
Information about any related health records that you don’t have but that we
can request on your behalf from a federal facility like a VA medical center or
clinic
If you think your service records don’t include a description of your
disability, you can also submit letters from family members, friends, clergy
members, law enforcement personnel, or those you served with that can tell us
more about your claimed condition and how and when it happened.
Note: In 1973, a fire at the National Personnel Records Center (NPRC) in St. Louis
destroyed records held for Veterans who were discharged from the Army and Air
Force during certain periods of time. If your records were destroyed in this fire,
you can get help reconstructing them.
Find out how to reconstruct your records (https://www.va.gov/records/get-
military-service-records/reconstruct-records)
Are there any risks to using the
Fully Developed Claims program?
No. Filing a fully developed claim won’t a\x00ect the attention we give to your claim
or the benefits you’re entitled to receive.

question: Are there any risks to using the Fully Developed Claims program?
ground_truths: ['No. Filing a fully developed claim won’t affect the attention we give to your claim or the benefits you’re entitled to receive.']
answer: No, there are no risks to using the Fully Developed Claims program. Filing a fully developed claim won't affect the attention given to your claim or the benefits you're entitled to receive.

If you think your service records don’t include a description of your
disability, you can also submit letters from family members, friends, clergy
members, law enforcement personnel, or those you served with that can tell us
more about your claimed condition and how and when it happened.
Note: In 1973, a fire at the National Personnel Records Center (NPRC) in St. Louis
destroyed records held for Veterans who were discharged from the Army and Air
Force during certain periods of time. If your records were destroyed in this fire,
you can get help reconstructing them.
Find out how to reconstruct your records (https://www.va.gov/records/get-
military-service-records/reconstruct-records)
Are there any risks to using the
Fully Developed Claims program?
No. Filing a fully developed claim won’t a\x00ect the attention we give to your claim
or the benefits you’re entitled to receive.
Learn what the PACT Act means for your VA benefits ', metadata={'source': '/Users/yinchangli/guardian/guardian/data/VA Fully Developed Claims Program _ Veterans Affairs.pdf', 'page': 1}), Document(page_content='11/19/23, 9:17 AM VA Fully Developed Claims Program | Veterans Affairs

program  to get a faster decision on your  disability
benefits claim  by sub m itting evidence along with your
claim .
Can I submit a fully developed
disability claim?
You can submit a fully developed disability claim if you’re applying for
compensation for:
An illness or injury (also called a condition) that was caused by—or got
worse because of—your active-duty service, or
A condition that was caused—or made worse—by a disability we’ve
already determined is service-connected
What do I need to do to submit a
fully developed claim?
For us to consider your claim fully developed, you’ll need to:
Submit your completed Application for Disability Compensation and
Related Compensation Benefits (VA Form 21-526EZ), and
Submit all the evidence (supporting documents) you have—or can
easily get—along with your claim, and
Certify that there’s no more evidence we might need to decide your
claim, and
Go to any VA medical exams required for us to decide your claim. We’ll
let you know if you need any exams.In this section

question: Should I work with a Veterans Service Officer (VSO) to file my claim?
ground_truths: ['You don’t have to, but we encourage you to work with an accredited VSO. These trained professionals can help you file your claim and gather the needed medical records and evidence.']
answer: Working with a Veterans Service Officer (VSO) can be beneficial as they are accredited representatives who can help you fill out your claim for disability compensation. However, the decision to work with a VSO is entirely up to you and depends on your comfort level with the process and the complexity of your claim.

[Document(page_content='11/19/23, 9:17 AM File for disability compensation with VA Form 21-526EZ | Veterans Affairs
https://www.va.gov/disability/ﬁle-disability-claim-form-21-526ez/introduction 2/3If you need help filing a disability claim, you can contact a VA regional o\x00ice and ask to speak to a
counselor. To find the nearest regional o\x00ice, please call 800-827-1000.
An accredited representative, like a Veterans Service O\x00icer (VSO), can help you fill out your claim.
Get help filing your claim (https://www.va.gov/disability/get-help-filing-claim/).
Apply
Complete this disability compensation benefits form. A\x00er submitting the form, you’ll get a
confirmation message. You can print this for your records.
VA review
We process applications in the order we receive them. The amount of time it takes to process your
claim depends on how many injuries or disabilities you claim and how long it takes us to gather
evidence needed to decide your claim.
Decision
Once we’ve processed your claim, you’ll get a notice in the mail with our decision. Disability rating s
For each disability we assign a rating from 0% to 100%. We base this rating on
the evidence you turn in with your claim. In some cases we may also ask you to
have an exam to help us rate your disability.
Before filing a claim for increase, you might want to check to see if you’re
already receiving the maximum disability rating for your condition.

https://www.va.gov/disability/how-to-ﬁle-claim/ 3/5How do I file a claim for
compensation?
You can file a claim\xa0online now.
You can also file for disability compensation in any
of these 3 ways
By mail
File your claim by mail using an Application for Disability Compensation and
Related Compensation Benefits (VA Form 21-526EZ).
Get VA Form 21-526EZ to download (https://www.va.gov/find-forms/about-form-
21-526ez)
Print the form, fill it out, and send it to this address:
Department of Veterans A\x00airs
Claims Intake Center
PO Box 4444
Janesville, WI 53547-4444
In person
Bring your application to a VA regional\xa0o\x00ice near you.
Find a VA regional o\x00ice near you (https://www.va.gov/find-locations/?
facilityType=benefits)
With the help of a trained professional
You can\xa0work with a trained professional called an accredited representative to
get help filing a claim for disability compensation.
Get help from an accredited representative (https://www.va.gov/disability/get-
help-filing-claim)File for disability compensation online
(https://www .va.gov/disability/file-disability-claim-form-21-526ez/)
